tweet: Bohemian rhapsody is the only logical response to @genetisaur’s multi-ancestry meta-analysis (MAMA) tool, I maintain #SMBE2018
.@genetisaur on the need for more diversity in GWAS - PRS do not transfer well across populations, which will only serve to increase health disparities #SMBE2018
@jnovembre Also, that the EEMS maps reflect physical geography (e.g. migration barriers at the Ural mountains) is amazing
Great talk by @jnovembre on inferring migration rates using spatial genomics - EEMS reflects patterns of classical methods like PCA but also finds additional information on migration #SMBE2018
.@jnovembre giving a lovely overview of geogenetic methods expanding on EEMS, HT to stepping stone model from Japanese gardens. #smbe2018

Last week I agreed to toast James Watson for the Human Genome Project on his 90th birthday. My brief comment about his being “flawed” did not go nearly far enough. His views are abhorrent: racist, sexist, anti-semitic. I was wrong to toast. I apologize.

We can’t pretend to support greater representation of women on the one hand (e.g. conversations like  https://twitter.com/averydavisbell/status/994013286671769601 … have become standard at the opening of Biology of Genomes meetings) … /8
Maša Roller: switches from promoter to enhancer or vice-versa can happen, but how often? These are extremely rare (2%) #BoG18
MR: Majority of promoters are shared across tissues (within and across species), but enhancers tend to be tissue-specific #BoG18
Maša Roller from @PaulFlicek group on tissue-specific enhancer and promoter evolution in mammals: previous work showed that promoters are far more stable across lineages #BoG18
.@erikgarrison vg removes reference bias, especially important for low-coverage data #BoG18

.@erikgarrison overall, pangenome does not appear to improve performance over bwa - but this is largely because reads matching the reference swamp the signal (reads containing a variant outperform) #BoG18
.@erikgarrison VG is publicly available:  https://github.com/vgteam/vg  #BoG18
Variation graph as “pan genomic object” - @erikgarrison shows examples. Markovian model with retained haplotype information. #BoG18
The wonderful @erikgarrison on variation graphs and why they might be useful #BoG18
+1! https://twitter.com/averydavisbell/status/994959427789840384 …
@OliverStegle @konradjk Just think: those of us in his group get to live this every day!
#BoG18 awesome "dynamicQTL" talk by @BennyStrobes. really makes the point that a static eQTL dataset from one timepoint probably is missing a lot! no wonder it's so hard to overlap GWAS with eQTLs...
.@BennyStrobes uses sparse matrix factorization to reveal temporal patterns #BoG18

.@BennyStrobes: Identify cis-eQTLs at each time step, correlate summary statistics across timesteps. Genetic regulatory patterns at closer timesteps correlate better than ones further apart (shared temporal dynamics) #BoG18
Benjamin Strober on genetic effects that depend on cell type. Instead of static snapshots of a single cell type/timepoint, measure iPSC differentiation over time #BoG18

.@OliverStegle: Clustering trait * locus correlations with each other (to detect shared effects) shows clustering primarily by loci. Suggests that the same loci have similar GxE effects across traits (rather than traits sharing effects indep of locus), extensive pleiotropy #BoG18
.@OliverStegle with new method StructLMM to detect GxE effects in UKBB - recover FTO locus for BMI (with diet/exercise lifestyle factors) #BoG18
It’s an intense topic but there is no one I’d rather hear it from early in the morning than @OliverStegle #BoG18 https://twitter.com/davisjmcc/status/994926213578854401 …
This #DoG18 #BoG18 https://twitter.com/TheTweetOfGod/status/994590734828236800 …

Top notch talk from @patrick_j_short reporting on work coming out of the DDD project. Really interesting analyses. But the bigger story really is how sickeningly good PhD students are these days. #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short: power to detect nucleotide level constraint = outlook is bleak. Going to need >1M genomes (Fun!) #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short nonetheless, element level constraint correlates with conservation. But nucleotide level conservation is even more important than element-level #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short looking towards non-coding constraint metric - need good understanding of germlibe mutation rate (many factors that lead to mu differences, regardless of selection) #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short: going to need hundreds of thousands of trios to truly find specific elements #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short outlook bleak for non-coding genome. No VEP equivalent, genes are longer (more power), and effect sizes lower in ncDNA #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short excess of recurrently mutated regions but no individual element reaches experiment wide significance (flat “East Anglia” plot) #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short discussing aspects of recent paper  https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25983 … #BoG18

.@patrick_j_short: using @ksamocha’s mutational model, can see enrichments for de novo coding variants. But less than half of patients have a coding variant. Are the rest regulatory? (Spoiler: probably not) #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short: “I was rejected from a summer camp here when I was 18, so hopefully I can redeem myself” #BoG18
.@patrick_j_short on de novo variants in regulatory elements in patients with neurodevelopmental disorders #BoG18

Talking this evening at #BoG2018 about my work on the contribution of mutations in regulatory elements in severe developmental disorders with @mehurles and @jcbarret. If you want more details, some of it is covered in this paper! https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25983 …

Rajbir Nath Batra on DNA methylation in breast cancer: towards understanding further subtypes and eventually personalized medicine. Epigenetic landscape pretty left out of previous work in this sphere. #BoG18
Rajbir N. Batra - On the complexity of breast cancer. Refers to MetaBRIC project  https://www.nature.com/articles/nature10983 … #BoG18
Trey Ideker on pathway architecture of cancer cells. Challenges include proper mapping and interpretation of pathways #BoG18
Bobbie Cansdale performing Hi-C to characterize TADs in the dog genome: genes that mediate similar phenotypes (e.g. coat color genes like KRT71) are often clustered within a Hi-C domain #BoG18 #DoG18
And now let's see if anyone has their volume on:  https://omfgdogs.com/  #BoG18 #DoG18
Did someone say Shiba Inu tail type? #BoG18 #DoG18 pic.twitter.com/YCDcPmZ0Wv
EO: "At the end of the talk, it makes sense to talk about the end of the dog" - GWAS for tail shape, curly tails in Shiba Inus #BoG18 #DoG18
EO: lincRNA SNP associated with ear pointiness, another gene associated with size - combination of these dictate overall ear shape #BoG18 #DoG18
EO savage burn on the Maltese - “do they even have legs.” (I feel she endorsed this tweet through reverse psychology)  #BoG18
EO: Leg length mediated by ESR1 expression. "And down here the Maltese have low [ESR1] expression, some people say they basically don't have legs" #BoG18 #DoG18
EO's effect sizes are crazy: 14 markers explain 95% of weight variation across dog breeds(!???) #BoG18 #DoG18
From @zaczap for that matter
EO performed GWAS across dog breeds, found dozens of associations across many traits, known and novel (LCORL popping up a few times: height, weight, longevity) #BoG18 #DoG18
EO: Using breed relatedness to narrow disease genes for each clade (similar diseases across distant breeds likely have different genetic basis) #BoG18 #DoG18
Another dog talk! Elaine Ostrander on a catalog of 722 WGS of dogs #BoG18 #DoG18 (borrowing a hashtag from Zach Zappala)

.@gsherloc searching for pleiotropy by evolving in one environment, pool and barcode, then introducing to new environment - lineages are on average beneficial across multiple environments, but many combinations exist (some specialist, some generalist) #BoG18

@NatalieTelis @gsherloc @konradjk @jkpritch Some quick summary stats for this meeting:-Organizers: 2/4 (50%)-Chairs: 6/14 (43%)-Keynotes: 1/2 (50%)-Speakers in the oral sessions: 22/56 (39%)-Speakers selected from abstracts: 15/40 (38%)-Attendees at the meeting: 174/479 (36%)@michaelhoffman @tuuliel @averydavisbell

Empirical distribution of @gsherloc fitness effects in yeast is an interesting look into SFS vs effect size: a few ~common variants with moderate effect, but rare variation abounds: a few of large effect, but many of small effect (we still have a long way to go in humans!) #BoG18

.@gsherloc uses experimental evolution (I have some fond memories of building baby chemostats using a precarious microwave-based sterilization and parafilm-fusing approach: good to know the original approaches were just as precarious to the point of going up in flames) #BoG18
Gavin Sherlock @gsherloc up next on exploring positive fitness effects in yeast #BoG18
BOSTON! I’ll be talking about “She Has Her Mother’s Laugh” at the Harvard Bookstore on May 30 at 7 pm.  http://www.harvard.com/event/carl_zimmer/ … pic.twitter.com/5GX2PMDa6Q

The refreshing thing about all the Neanderthal talks so far at #BoG18 is that they start with the whole genome, and *then* look for Neanderthal-related patterns/enrichments (rather than looking at only archaic variants and drawing potentially biased inferences)

KM finds strong sweeps on X chromosome - as a naive observer, is there a reason these haven't these been found before (e.g. by @rdhernand and folks - I see some mentions of X, but nothing to this extent)? Is the data just better now? #BoG18
KM using interesting new method from @SkovLaurits and Durbin for detecting archaic introgression without an archaic reference  https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2018/03/23/283606 … #BoG18
Kasper Munch on selective sweeps on the X chromosome in OOA (removing Neandertal admixture 🤔) using SGDP data #BoG18

@averydavisbell Of note, most of the people at the Racker didn’t realise this was part of the presentation and we all looked at the person closest to the screen thinking that was his mobile phone. #BoG18

Arang Rhie: Genome 10k vertebrate genomes project - building de novo ref genomes for all vertebrate orders. For research, evolutionary analyses, and to preserve info on species nearing extinction. A very worthy goal! #BoG18
Monica Justice with a tour de force of dredging the mouse genome for modifier mutations for Rett syndrome, identified lipid modulation and DDR as new therapeutic entry points #BoG18

I am looking for postdocs to join my new group @sangerinstitute and work on rare/common disease genetic architecture and pop gen in populations with high levels of parental relatedness. Come and chat to me at #BoG18!  https://tinyurl.com/yaqw6jlh   https://tinyurl.com/ycw9f9wm  https://twitter.com/hilsomartin/status/989888319076159490 …

Job Dekker - Intro: Spatial arrangement of the genome is key to understand function. Over the years, 3C, 4C, 5C, Hi-C. Interphase chromosomes are compartmentalised (TADs). CTFC sites at boundaries of TADs #BoG18
Smart folks jumping the gun for wine and cheese #BoG18 pic.twitter.com/o7qV0lhf84
Allele specific chromatin accessibility in stimulated immune cells elucidates some cool biology on shared chromatin profiles, poster 49 by @diegoisworking
A very spicy poster #56 - genetic diversity of peppers, complete with GWAS for pepper shape #BoG18
#BoG18 Hayward should do audio books!!
PA showing very cool visual of shared alleles back in time - can observe OOA bottleneck and human common ancestor #BoG18
PA: what fraction of _your genome_ is shared with _another genome_ back in time? Using allele aging approach genome-wide to show similarities between pairs of genomes #BoG18
PA: Using their method, estimate that the lactase persistence allele arose ~18K years ago #BoG18
PA: GEVA outperforms PSMC for more recent events (in simulations if I understood correctly?) #BoG18
PA combines coalescent models to delimit the mutation between other mutational events, and overlays shared haplotype data to estimate allele age #BoG18
Patrick Albers on non-parametric estimation of allele age for rare variants in population sequencing data, work with @gil_mcvean #BoG18
AK: rtQTLs are enriched at binding of pluripotency factors (headed off my question!: often found in the TF binding motif itself!) #BoG18
AK performed GWAS on replication timing differences (rtQTL): veritable Dubai plot of a single association for a single replication event #BoG18

AK now looking at replication timing in hESCs from WGS of many lines - see reproducible, clean data that allow prediction of location of replication origins. Some vary among individuals, some seem necessary #BoG18
Amnon Koren on using HTS to measure replication timing: copy number in dividing cells reflects replication timing #BoG18

Dog talks really are some of the best talks (if for no other reason than the visuals) #BoG18

.@TheNobleDust did saturation genome editing on 2 domains (13 exons) of BRCA1, edited in 97% of the possible SNVs. Assayed each based on cell survival to create a functional score that strongly correlates with annotation, Clinvar status #BoG18

As I've been saying, your ability to predict skin color in ancient DNA samples with a handful of SNPs is _seriously_ questionable. Consider this: you need 258 SNPs to explain 20% of the variation in hair color (a simpler trait than skin color) in *modern* Europeans. (2/3)
